title: Arduino Nano / 1.8" TFT LCD Projects Enclosure

description.text: Take an Arduino Nano, mount it on a custom designed PCB with a 1.8" TFT LCD and some input buttons, enclose it in a custom designed, 3D Printed Case (that you are looking at now), and you have a versatile and attractive  platform for your project.   The PCB is designed to be completed with headers that expose all of the pins of the Arduino Nano for access by jumpers (though connections could be soldered rather than using the headers).   The case and PCB provide for a 5v power plug though power can be provided via the USB connection as well.   Leads for inputs and outputs can be run through a slot provided for that purpose or that slot can be fitted with a six pin header that can then be used for jumpers (with jumpers inside the case completing the circuit to the desired Nano pins).  Please see this page for more information about options.

No special instructions for printing the case. It should just print. The DeepBack option can be used to stuff more electronics into the case with the Nano. Instructions for assembly of the entire kit can be found on Instructables: http://www.instructables.com/id/Assembling-an-Arduino-Nano-LCD-Projects-Platform/ The electronics bits that comprise this project can be purchased on eBay (UK): http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/201387701742?ssPageName=STRK:MESELX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1555.l2649 If the eBay listing is not active try searching for "Arduino Nano / 1.8" TFT LCD Projects Enclosure"

Tower of Emmeloord (Poldertoren) http://www.emmeloord.info/poldertoren
Shaft

There you are working on you giant mansion minding your own business when you walk outside for a smoke. As you light up you realize it has gotten really quiet, then as you try to sprint back for your door. SSSSSssssSSSssSS. It is to late you have been caught by the creeper. As you die in the fiery explosion you think, man this is gonna suck. Walking back to your home from the hospital you find all of you stuff laying in the hole that used to be your yard. Now you can play pranks on your friends and spawn your own army of creepers to take over the world. I present the Parametric Creeper, this model is based off the scale sizes that I found to make a Scale creeper in game, based off one block per pixel. I then modified them to be parametric and built an OpenSCAD script to generate the models.Below are the figures for the statue I used, and should be the same as the pixel count for a creeper skin: Head: 8x8x8
Body: 12x8x4
Feet: 6x8x4 The head of the creeper is exactly half a normal block, so if you want to make other Minecraft items the above figures, blocks are 16x16 with what ever your scaling is. The .stl files that I have included are all at an 8x scale, with the OpenSCAD file included to scale it up or down. Disclaimer: The Creeper and anything else related to minecraft is owned by Markus Persson aka Notch and Mojang AB. I claim no rights to anything but the wild idea to make my own creeper. I loved the game and everything they are doing so you should support them if you aren't already. Note: I am putting this as a Attribution - Creative Commons license simply because I don't know what else to put it as. If anyone from Mojang has a problem with this model or the Licensing that I have set for it let me know and I will change it. Update 1: The .stls provided below are at 8x scale. This makes the creeper come out to about 8 inches. I will be uploading a standardized scale .stl at a later date. As I work on the rest of a set of minecraft models I learn how huge these things are. It looks as though the animals won't print on my makerbot hence the change in scaling, when I get one that works for everything. I was not in the right mind when I started this project but the creeper keeps telling me that I must finish or he will explode. Hopefully the minecraft guy http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8381 will save me when he respawns. Update 2: As with my other models I have cleaned up the code for this one commenting it and making it more standard and easier to use. I have also generated the Creeper in the new 5x scale models. No inline magnet support yet but that is due to the differences in magnets. Hopefully with the commenting it will be easier to add magnets.

• Print 1 of each Head, Body and Leg set. Preferably in a green color.

  • Using markers or paint color in the toes on the legs and the face of the creeper.

  • Attach legs to the body.
    At the 8x scale 3mm filament works perfect. cut off 8 small piece and use as connectors. Glue in place either by melting with acetone or using super glue.

  • Place head on body.
    The print layers on mine allow the head and body to stick together fairly well with mine while allowing the head to spin. It has been suggested to add support for magnets to hold everything together but I haven't tried as of yet.

  • Run away from it and don't ever approach for fear of explosions.
    • Warning: Author not responsible for any damages caused by exploding creepers. Anyone that plays Minecraft knows full well how dangerous they can be. If you are crazy enough to bring one of the demon things into the world you are responsible for any havoc that they may cause.

description.text:
My son complained that there was no railway crossing for the new Lego City Train - only a crossing for the old (incompatible) Lego Tracks exists. This poor child has to play with my old toys ;-) ... and I remember from my childhood, that I hated this clumsy big blue crossing, because it was not possible to cross two close parallel tracks. Luckily times have changed.  
Here is a Mini-Railway-Crossing for the new Lego City Train. The smaller design allows to cross tons of close parallel tracks. Top and bottom sides interlock with basic Lego bricks.

description.text:
This is a bass guitar - or guitar - holder that mounts on a shelf. Convenient if you lack space, and have a number of shelfs you can actually mount stuff on. Especially if the shelves contain stuff you don't use all the time. :-)  
The source is scad, with tons of variables in the start, so you can adjust e.g. the thickness of your shelf (12 mm in model).

You need to split the model in your slicer into the holder and the screw.  
I had success printing in PLA 0.3 mm, using infill of 25%. It need to be quite strong to be able to carry a bass guitar, that is somewhat heavy.

title: iamburny's Customizable Text - Name Keyring / Keyfob

description.text:
Find the new simplified v2 Name Keyring maker here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1148986 now with sliders for spacing and height adjustment Customizable Text Keyring, make one for your significant other! show them that the expense is justified after all!! Uses the recently added openSCAD text() function, which allows the use of almost any regular font. Change Log: Version 1.4: 22/11/2015
  • Added a few more fonts that work OK
  • Added Loop Y position adjustment (suggested by shadow651, thanks)
  • Tidied the settings menus
  • Refined the range slider amounts
  • Added some name examples using the newly added fonts
    • Version 1.3: - 16/11/2015
  • Fixed missing customizer after thingiverse changed the customizer code
  • Added ability to change the letter and font used to form the loop, helpful for names that dont start with a vertical letter (use the letter 'o' instead of a 'u')
  • Example with # hashtag added
  • Tweaked preview rotation to save better STL view
  • Added a whole load more examples :)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Ormerod

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%
Uses the recently added openSCAD text() function, which allows the use of almost any regular font.

• Choose a Font

  • Enter the text you want, it works best with <10 letters

  • Adjust the spacing of the characters so they touch each other, you must enter an array containing the same amount of number as you have letters (e.g. [12.5,12.5,12,10.5,10] for 5 letter name)

  • Adjust the height of each letter, between 5 and 10mm works best, you must enter an array containing the same amount of number as you have letters (e.g. [10,7.5,8.8,7.5,10] for 5 letter name)

  • Tweak the twist and center as desired.

  • Adjust the key loop position so it is touching the first letter

  • Check it over with the Rotation slider
    • Print It!
    I printed mine in PLA with a 0.2mm layer height.

author: dukeisi

description.text: I found three videos of visual proofs of the Pythagorean Theorem which I decided to use with my classes. I like these videos because they are strictly visual, no audio explanation. Once my students figure out how the proofs work, they have to explain them either in writing or on video. I created this and two other puzzles to go along with these videos. The video for this puzzle can be found at https://youtu.be/10rSltql2Vg.

Everything is ready to print.  I made separate files so parts could be printed the same colors as in the video.  I also shrank the puzzle pieces to 97% so they would fit better in the puzzle frame.  I based all three puzzles on a 3 cm by 4 cm by 5 cm right triangle so many of the pieces are interchangeable between puzzles.  The only downside is that the videos don't use the same size right triangle so the puzzles look a little different.

author: csup_propel

description.text: This is a simple sucker. The hole is of 7 mm of diameter and the surface diameter is of 37 mm.

I had a need to slowly move a pinion gear on a rack. Using a DC Motor controller with my small hobby motors to lower the RPM, I had to sacrifice torque. A gearbox was my solution. This is a generic but customizable gearbox, that exposes (via arcs in the face) two sides of the "driving" gear so that you can "engage" your motor. Your motor can be attached via your bracket (that you print), through the mounting holes on the faces. A bracket for a "DC 3-12V Gearmotor for ARDUINO Robot Smart Car" has been included. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nSY02jBna0w

Materials:
  • 8 off 4G x 9mm self tapping button head screws.
  • 2 off 2mm wires 25mm long (thin coat-hanger wire).
  • 2 off 608 skate bearings (OD 22mm, ID 8mm, W 7mm).
  • Print one of each face.
  • Print 4 of 16.5mm spacers.
  • Print one axle.
  • Print one of each bearing spacer.
  • Print 2 of 4.5mm gear spacer.
  • Print 3 of 1mm gear spacer.
  • Print 1 of keyed single gear.
  • Print 3 of double gears.
  • Print 1 of MotorGear.
  • Optional: Print 1 of Motor bracket (if the included one does not suit, design and print your own).
  • Optional: hardware for mounting motor to bracket (2 x 25mm M3 screw and nut for 1 supplied).
    • Assembling the gearbox:
  • Drill "out" the 2mm holes in the faces, gear spacers and gears.
  • Lightly file the rough print surface on all parts.
  • Put a dab of petroleum jelly/grease on touching surfaces.
  • Press 1 off skate bearing into each face, flush with non-bed surface of print.
  • Press 2 off 2mm wires into 2mm holes in rough side of square face.
  • Fasten 1 off 16.5mm spacer in each corner with 1 off 4G x 9mm screws. The spacers will be on the same side as the wires.
  • Position face with wires up, and bearing to the top on a flat surface.
  • Insert 1mm gear spacer on right-side wire.
  • Insert double gear on right-side wire, small gear down.
  • Insert 4.5mm gear spacer on left-side wire.
  • Insert double gear on left-side wire, small gear down, meshing gears of left and right side.
  • Insert 1mm gear spacer on right-side wire.
  • Insert double gear on right-side wire, small gear down, meshing gears of left and right side.
  • Insert 4.5mm gear spacer on left-side wire.
  • Insert the remaining face onto the two wires, with the arc's to the right and bottom.
  • Fasten the 4 corners with 4G x 9mm screws leaving about 0.5mm gap from face to spacer.
  • Prepare the single gear, axle, bearing spacers so they are a firm but adjustable fit; pull them apart.
  • Insert the keyed single gear resting and centred on the bottom bearing, meshing with the lower small gear.
  • Turn the gearbox housing on its left side.
  • Pass the axle through the bearings and the single gear in there current positions.
  • From the right pass the smaller bearing spacer over the axle and into the bearing, flush with the outside of the bearing.
  • From the left side pass the larger bearing spacer over the axle and into the bearing, flush with the outside of the bearing. The thinner side will be inside the gearbox.
  • Test by rotating the "driving gear" (the one closest to the arcs) with your fingers.
  • Tighten or loosen one side of the screws to suit.
    • Assembling the motor mount:
  • Carefully push the axle so it is flush with the bearing on the square side.
  • With the square face down and bearing to the top, remove the lower 2 corner spacers completely.
  • Insert the motor mount into the face corners, with flat face up.
  • Fasten with 4G x 9mm screws (removed).
  • Place motor gear onto motor axle (side without a dimple).
  • Line up holes on motor with holes in motor mount, engaging the gears.
  • Fastem M3 scews through motor and mount with nuts in mount slots.
  • Carefully power up and tweak M3 and 4G screws to suit.
    • Adjusting ratios with supplied parts:
  • Remove or add pairs of double gears.
  • Create new corner spacers to new width using CornerSpacerMM.dxf (extruded).
  • Print 4 corner spacers.
  • Replace 2mm wires with ones adjusted to new width.
  • Assemble as above.
    • Adjusting ratios with custom parts:
  • Work out desired configuration with paired gears, keyed gear and motor gear needing to match tooth specs.
  • Print paired gears with large gear extruded 3mm, the small gear extruded a further 4mm and 2mm central hole cut.
  • Print keyed gear at 3mm extrusion and the axle vector (smallest curve in MotorGearMM.dxf) cut central.
  • Print the motor gear with the gear extruded 3mm to suit your motor (DXF included as a guide).
  • Treating the bearing hole as fixed work out new positions of new 2mm wire holes.
  • Print both faces using the supplied DXF's extruded to 5mm. The 2mm wire holes will need to be moved to the new layout (#4).
  • Assemble as above.

By request of Syvwlch ( http://www.thingiverse.com/syvwlch ) and WilliamAAdams ( http://www.thingiverse.com/WilliamAAdams ), here is a stand-alone public-domain OpenSCAD cycloidal speed reducer. As with the Wankel Engine and Roots Blower I recently posted, this is intended more as an example of an interesting mechanism than as a practical device. If you want a practical printable speed reducer, you might consider one of the other alternatives like the worm drives on this Tank http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8080 or
differential planetary gears http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7390 or
cascaded spur gears http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7379 or
this planetary gear reducer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8460 There are several cycloidal-type mechanisms already on Thingiverse, such as
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3617 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3736 There are also several interesting external sites like:
http://www.zincland.com/hypocycloid/
http://fabricationsofthemind.com/2010/07/09/extruder-design-1-printable-1001-hypocycloidal-gearbox/
https://github.com/triffid/Differential_Hypocycloid
http://reprap.org/wiki/Differential_Hypocycloid
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerotor
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gear_pump and many many interesting youtube videos such as
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bRn1K2XeWVE
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3WvPF6uGCq4
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CG2sPuqEXBg
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AMtyFwMDL7w
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h236SP86nnQ This present script is based on a design by M.F. Hill described in his 1928 patent "Internal Rotor", number 1,682,563: http://www.google.com/patents/about?id=mdF5AAAAEBAJ&dq=1682563 Note that this design is based on an offset hypocycloid, similar to Figure I in Hill's patent. Most of the contemporary designs appear to be based on an offset epicycloid, more closely resembling Figure V in the patent. The motivated student can modify the code so it generates epicycloidal-based profiles. Hint: start by making a module ``epitrochoidBandFast(n, r, thickness, r_off)". The motivated student could also probably clean up my train-wreck of code and/or figure out how to do arrays in OpenSCAD. Note also that these rotors can be used for pumps - see the gifs in the comments for an example.

OpenSCAD for animate!
STLs for print!
DXF for cut! The minimum clearance around shafts is about 0.6mm. If printed, there might be a little interference at the tips of the internal rotor lobes. The DXFs have the same profile as the STLs, so the beam kerf should provide ample clearance if anyone actually lasercuts it. There are some extra holes in the DXF profiles so pieces can be aligned and bolted/screwed together. Yet-another-Note: The DXF files were generated directly from OpenSCAD. I am not sure why they preview as having dotted lines in some places, but when viewed with say, Open Office Draw, the lines appear solid.

comments.text: Tapering or replacing by bolts is a good idea, but I have not added anything like that.  There are probably a number of practical problems that would need to be solved if someone wanted to use this in a real application.  It would also probably be necessary to add some type of ball or roller bearing to the eccentric to reduce friction.  The pin extrusions on the driven shaft may also have to be replaced with rollers.

Have you ever had this happen to you? http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:636350 It did for me. I designed this to prevent future door damage. By increasing the surface area of the door contact, the force on the door is significantly reduced.

Simply print and replace the original cap. This is meant for the fixed side and not the adjustable side. Since the door stop is not cast to precision, you might need to scale the the part to match your door stop. Depending on your printer, you may or may not need support.

description.text: This slotted rail can be used to create all sorts of structures. The slots can be used as mounting points for various sliding fixtures.

Print two halves, and then slide them together; they fit together like puzzle pieces.
No support material is required.
The STL file is for a 1 inch X 1 inch X 12 inch rail. I have included the original SolidWorks 2010 design file for anybody who wishes to modify the design (i.e. changing the length).

title: The ultimate gear sphere - Re-Remix DIN912
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Remix of the 2x scaled Version of the ultimat gear sphere. printed in laywood and laybrick. core in abs. files are modified to work with DIN 912 Screws Size: M6x20mm the core is hollowed by a 40mm sphere wich saves around 2m filament and 30min printing
time for me...

you need:
32x M6x20mm Screws
1x Core_hollowed_DIN_912.stl
12x Plug_DIN_912.stl
8x Small_Gear_DIN_912.stl
10x Big_Gear_DIN_912.stl
2x Big_Gear_dent_DIN_912.stl
-OR-
2x Big_Gear_knobed_DIN_912.stl complete parts print time in my case: ~11hours the holes for the screws have 6.3mm at the M6 part and 11mm for the head of the screw. Scaling Tips:
50% (0.5 in slic3r) should give you 3,15 and 5,5mm. M3 Screw is 2,9 and 5,4mm -> should fit, but could get a bit tight at the head of the screw... 83,33% (0.833) for M5
66,66% (0.666) for M4
or if you can´t get enough
133% (1.333) for M8
:)

A simple 2 bladed propeller with really nice blades copied from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:172801 I've tried to copy the dimensions from a generic 5*3" propeller that I got from this set:
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Mini-250-Quadcopter-1806-2280kv-Motor-12A-Esc-CC3D-Flight-Control-5030-Propeller-CC3D-Distribution-LED/32297309822.html To get a (nearly) valid STL as the one you find under the "Thing Files" tab, you need to open the STL file you export from OpenSCAD in MeshLab and apply the filter "Cleaning and Repairing" -> "Remove Duplicate Faces". This still leaves you with a few errors, but its close enough to be sliceable with Slic3r. see also:
http://forum.openscad.org/Visually-and-by-inspecting-code-surface-looks-perfect-But-quot-Object-may-not-be-a-valid-2-manifold--td12686.html The first set of files I've uploaded is a CCW prop, now I've added a CW prop with a more sensible filename. They are lying upside down since on the downside the center ring hole is 1.5*1.5mm bigger then the rest of the hole (which is 5mm) which of course is better printable when this bigger hole faces up. The wings can only be printed with support material either way. UPDATE: Since this prop has much too little lift, I've created a new version with bigger wings, see files. To circumvent problems with the resulting STL files, I've instead based this new version on a cleaned up STL containing a single wing -> "mywing_ml3.stl" UPDATE 2015-05-31 today I've tested a few prints of the "big-wing" variant and unlike expected I got much less lift with it then the original design. Next I'm gonna try something much simpler: "redesigned-wing_2D_v3.stl" UPDATE 2015-06-01 Since by now I've printed and tested a lot of props (I'm trying to get usable propellers with which I can fly my quadcopter to bridge the time till my prop-shipment arrives) I've assembled a list with how much lift every print that I have tried gave me (meassured by strapping the quadcopter to kitchen scales, and just turning on the one motor by usign the cleanflight configurator motor test tool) original prop delivered with my quadcopter set -> between 280g and 300g
"5x3prop_CCW" (first design) -> 135g
"big-wings_v2" -> 60g
"redesigned-wing_2D_v3" -> 170g
"prop5x3x2_v7" -> 207g
"prop5x3x2_v8" -> 158g
"prop5x3x2_v8" after bending the rear ends of the wings down (with a soldering iron heated to 190°C and a flat ending) -> 184g
"prop5x3x2_v9" -> around 230g I've stopped work on this project, since my delivery of replacement props finally arrived ;) If you're interested in the story "behind" these propellers, see http://koega.no-ip.org/mediawiki/index.php/Building_a_quadcopter

I found three videos of visual proofs of the Pythagorean Theorem which I decided to use with my classes. I like these videos because they are strictly visual, no audio explanation. Once my students figure out how the proofs work, they have to explain them either in writing or on video. I created this and two other puzzles to go along with these videos. The video for this puzzle can be found at https://youtu.be/vQW4JzxVwCk.

Everything is ready to print. I made separate files so parts could be printed the same colors as in the video. I also shrank the puzzle pieces to 97% so they would fit better in the puzzle frame. I based all three puzzles on a 3 cm by 4 cm by 5 cm right triangle so many of the pieces are interchangeable between puzzles. The only downside is that the videos don't use the same size right triangle so the puzzles look a little different.

I found three videos of visual proofs of the Pythagorean Theorem which I decided to use with my classes. I like these videos because they are strictly visual, no audio explanation. Once my students figure out how the proofs work, they have to explain them either in writing or on video. I created this and two other puzzles to go along with these videos. The video for this puzzle can be found at https://youtu.be/LyGmcLSvJg8.

Everything is ready to print. I made separate files so parts could be printed the same colors as in the video. I also shrank the puzzle pieces to 97% so they would fit better in the puzzle frame. I based all three puzzles on a 3 cm by 4 cm by 5 cm right triangle so many of the pieces are interchangeable between puzzles. The only downside is that the videos don't use the same size right triangle so the puzzles look a little different.  This puzzle has a few more pieces than my other Pythagorean puzzles.  There are extra triangles as well as two frame pieces that fit together (had too much trouble trying to print it as a single piece with my size print bed).

title: Metric Holes 1mm-20mm in 1mm steps x 20mm tall

description.text:
Made this to use as a gauge for future holes in projects.
The Height can be determined when you print.
I printed mine using ABS, Height was @75% so 15mm
with 3 outer layers. with .1mm layers. Also the spacing in between holes is no less than 3mm anywhere on the part. You can then decide on a hole. and count upwards to downwards to determine the real world hole size you will end up with also premised on your settings at the time of print. Which Ill print on a ziplock bag to use as storage for this part. ** Post print completion.
The Draft on the part needs a small amount of cleaning up. its completely evident on the 1mm hole. on the bottom side? no hole. on the top side you can see the hole. My top part did not complete the 3 layers as requested (Im trying out a new slicer(Simplify3d)) But aside from the hiccup Im quite pleased with the part. the holes did come out larger as expected. now I have a base line for future holes. Also I tried to shoot for a shape that was easy to hold and did not take up any wasted space. I'll be making one based on common fractions soon.
Thx.

As the dawn space craft has begun orbiting ceres I thought I'd try and turn the images coming back into a 3D model. The poles lack detail due to the combination of Dawns orbit, the sun and the limits of the photogammetry software I'm using (agisoft photoscan). Essentially I could only map those areas not in too much shade. I hope to make a better model when NASA releases more images. The source of the NASA images:
http://dawn.jpl.nasa.gov/multimedia/images/
I broke the gif animation into frames and used a blank black mask with a tolerance of 150 in photoscan to mask areas in too much shadow. Any less was resulting in warped models. I then used blender to add a sphere to the model in order to fill out the poles. I then passed it back to photoscan to generate a texture. Then back to blender to texture paint the poles. Also if you like this you can see my later designs or contact me via Website: https://www.anthromod.com

I had a need for a customized breadboard that would allow me to use it inside a small prop, which would allow me to to continue to build and modify it without permanently soldering a circuit together.  
So here is my concept for a Modular breadboard. After some suggestions from the community I remodeled the bits to use the clips that exist in breadboards. The idea that you can buy a few uber cheap breadboard online to harvest the clips within. In an ideal world, it would be great of there was a way to buy these clips that allow a user to cut as much as they need to insert into a custom breadboard layout. Only in a perfect world.  
Even if you don't want to destroy a perfectly good breadboard, you can use aluminum foil or even shape you're own clips by cutting up a can of soda. Granted these options require more work.  
Freecad Source included if you want to have a head start making you're own bits.

comments.text: Awesome idea, thanks for sharing these handy models!

description.text:
A small frag rack for my little 2 gallon fluval spec.
I just wanted a small rack for my corals that wouldn't take up too much space in my tank. It has places for 5 little magnets from a Magnetix toy in the back which should be sufficient. I haven't tested it yet, so I'm not sure if there will be a bouyancy issue. Also, you will have to cover up the exposed magnets so that they don't contact the saltwater, I plan to use silicone.
Once I start using it, I'll post pictures.
I printed it in ABS plastic with a 50% infill.

This is one of our earlier experiments in printing soft microstructures. It is a 6x6x6 tiling of 10-3-a pattern. Each cell is of size 5mm, and each rod is ~0.5mm thick. See video at https://youtu.be/C514tdchCRc Special thanks to Prof. George Hart for explaining this pattern through email. Please see more 10-3-a pattern at http://www.georgehart.com/rp/10-3.html

The intent was to design a mini roll bender to be used to perfectly bend aluminum tubes of small diameters (about 8mm with a wall thickness of 1mm maximum) This was to help in building a basketball hoop in replacement of my thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:582302 that was all in printed materials (and destroyed by too many slam dunks) I can print it again and again, but I prefer to make a new one with a stronger construction made in mixed part printed and not, but ove all I want to have perfect ring made of aluminum. To made the aluminum ring I need obiouvsly an aluminum tube, that I find in a local store, and a roll bender, so I made one printable. Unfortunately I've been too optimistic and it has result too weak to work correctly. (also if printed with 90%infill) So you've been warned that IT DOESN'T WORK ! I decided to post it in anyhow cause probably could be enough for weaker tubes or could be a start or an idea for another thing In any case could be a nice tabletop ornament !

description.text:
EDIT 1/10/2017: Finally got around to printing the model! Check the instructions below for slicer settings and tips.
EDIT 8/17/2015: Added "HighRes ToT Arch (Repaired) STL" for easy printing! I created this model to test my printer's capacity to handle overhang as well as calibrate its retraction settings. Printing instructions and slicer settings are listed below. I hope that you enjoy the model, and if you do please let me know!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Print two of HighRes_ToT_Arch_Repaired_STL.stl and glue them together to form the completed shape. Alternatively just keep the arch by itself. The make shown was printed on my Ultimaker 2 using PLA. I sliced the model in Cura (I had to scale the model down to 80%) with the following print settings: TIP: The very bottom of the model is quite small; strong bed adhesion is recommended. It may be easier to print if you "sink" the model into the buildplate by translating the model in the negative Z axis just a bit (so that the model has a larger footprint). Temperature: 200 C
Build Plate Temp: 65 C
Infill: 20%
Print Speed: 50 mm/s
Travel Speed: 125 mm/s
Layer Height: 0.15 mm
Build Plate Adhesion: Brim with 10 mm width
Wall Thickness: 1.05 mm (3 lines)
ZHop when retracted is enabled
NO SUPPORTS!

Post Processing Printing without supports may lead to some drooping. However after going over the entire structure with a good craft knife and cutting it all off, it looked perfectly fine. Also, I realized that the two halves didn't quite sit flush, so I sanded the ends of each a bit until it fit a bit better. I held the bottom half of the arch in a clamp and dabbed some Gorilla Glue over all the edges, pushing the two halves together, then letting the glue dry. That's it!

About the Design This particular fractal is a slight tweak from CmdrChaos's "Low Calorie Torus" (http://cmdrchaos.deviantart.com/art/Low-Calorie-Torus-344056205). My version simply tweaks some of the totoricalIFS values (specifically mulA1 and subA1). This model was created using Mandelbulb 3D, a free fractal rendering software.

Eat your heart out Bear Grills!
(more pics coming soon)
Features include:
standard utility knife blades (with 3 spares stored in handle)
paracord wrapping on handle
Handle slotted to fit to a Mini-Bic lighter
Neck sheath w/ lanyard Vitamin list:
a little sheet metal screw to secure the blade retainer
4 utility blades
3 feet of paracord or similar
mini-bic lighter If you want to remix this project, I suggest finding a way to integrate a whistle and/or compass into the sheath.

Print it.
trim off the round feet
fit a blade into the slot and press the blade retainer into place.
Secure it with a little sheet metal screw, using the back of a spare blade to twist the screw into place.
Fit the lighter and spare blades into place.
Wrap the handle with 12" of electrical or duct tape (handy stuff!)
Wrap the handle with 3 feet of parachute cord.
*Test fit the neck sheath. Use your new knife to trim the snap-on retention tabs to fine-tune the fit.

description.text:
I needed a small customizable strap for some printed wearable projects I've been working on and decided to use some of my NinjaFlex to make one. This one is surprisingly strong and easy to use and didn't need any hard plastic parts to make it hold together. You can even fold over extra strap material and connect it to keep it out of the way (look at the last photo).  
[UPDATE_1]: I added a modified version of the strap with more holes so it could be used as a cable tie, or just wrap it around something smaller. I also added a tab to the very end to make it easier to pull and connect it, or remove it.  
[UPDATE_2]: After a recommendation from a friend I made a new strap design that loops through itself so it can be used as a cable tie, or in a lot of other different ways. I like it because it lets you tuck away extra length of strap so it's not flopping around. I also added two longer straps, the longest of which can fit around a larger Nalgene bottle. Both require a large print bed, but can obviously be sized down.

I use an E3D Volcano hot-end and used the 0.6mm nozzle with a layer height of 0.3mm and 2 'shells'. Speed was about 15mm/s and print temp was around 218C.   
These are also printed on a modified gMax 1.0 printer by gCreate (gcreate.com), which has a large enough build area to accommodate the larger strap sizes. If oriented at an angle most may fit normal size build platforms.

comments.text: I use SketchUp's 3D Text tool to create the name.  Then use the Explode option on the drop down menu when you right click on the text.  This separates the letters. comments.text: Thanks @CorneliusJD.  I included the sketchup file also in case anyone wants to make them a bit bulkier, or needs a bigger screw hole.  I am kind of up in the air, as far as my own usage, if I want it a bit bulkier.
comments.author: CorneliousJD

comments.text: Hey @TurboRaddo, so I did print one of these (also remixed it, check it out!) but I think you just need to make them a little thicker (taller on the Z the way it prints) because my screw fit just about perfect in the hole, but there's so little structure on the sides of the hole that it split open. It still totally works but just a tip. Maybe expand it by a bit and make the hole ever-so-slightly bigger and I think you've got a winner!
comments.author: 3DPrintingNewb

comments.text: @corenliousJD, I was thinking the same thing.  I ended up not printing anymore of the original sizing.  I just uploaded v2 that is now 10mm thick and printed out 5 of them.  It allows for more spacing on the sides of the screws and now allows for the #8 screws to be used.  It also feels a lot stronger than the original version.  Love your remix combining it with the bracket.
comments.author: CorneliousJD
